key_points: The Senate voted 57-43 in the second impeachment trial of President Donald Trump.
43 Republican senators voted not to convict Trump, with various explanations provided.
Some senators voted in support of Trump, stating the House Managers did not prove their case.
Others believed the Senate lacked jurisdiction to try a former president, despite the House Managers proving their case.
A number of senators did not express their view on the merits, but also cited lack of jurisdiction.
It is technically incorrect to consider some of the 43 votes as a vote to 'acquit' based on questions of guilt or innocence.
Over half of the 43 senators were critical of Trump or were neutral regarding his guilt or innocence.
An overwhelming majority of the 100 senators who considered guilt or innocence voted to convict.
Sen. Chris Coons (D-DE) suggested that further accountability for Trump could be pursued through other means, such as a criminal trial or disqualification from holding future office.
The explanations given by the 43 Republican senators might indicate their openness to future legislative actions against Trump.
